title: How many octaves can I sing if I can sing from A#3 to B5? Also whats the difference if a note has like the little ‘#’ in it? Sorry, I’m stupid. - Quora

response.answer_text: “Octaves” are represented by the number next to the note, so being able to sing from A#3 to B5 is a two octave range, which is about average. “#” signifies the note is “sharp”, so A# is A Sharp. Look at this piano here:  Notice that there are notes on each white key, and in-between most notes, there is a black key. Those black keys represent “sharp” and “flat” notes. Basically “sharp” and “flat” notes are the notes in-between most “natural” notes. A# or A Sharp would be the note in-between A and B. You could also call it “Bb” or “B flat“, since these notes can either be referred to as the [Lower note] Sharp, or [Higher note] flat. Also take notice of the fact that “B Sharp”, or “E Sharp” don’t exist on the piano, it’s a whole weird thing where the sound frequency that would theoretically “B Sharp”/“E Sharp” is actually just a “C Natural”/“F Natural” respectively, so those don’t really exist in music.
